loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is married. She is an entrepreneur from Vinogradovo. Galina runs a small business selling stuffed toys. She usually buys toys wholesale and then travels to remote towns and villages to sell them at retail prices to earn her income. Galina can always boast a nice selection of merchandise, which is a considerable advantage in this competitive market.  

Galina has been in this business for 6 years. Presently, she has about 30,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Her gross income is about 10,000 Grivnyas. Monthly profit amounts to 4,000 Grivnyas. Galina is now seeking a loan of 9,500 Grivnyas to increase assorted merchandise this holiday season and get additional income.

loans.use: to increase her turnover capital

loans.name: Lucia Isabel

texts.es: La señora  Lucia G.  tiene 31 años de edad, es Casada  habita junto  a su esposo  e hijos, ella y su esposo se dedican al mismo oficio llevan 12 años de laborar en la artesanía  “Confección de delantales Típicos para mujeres” su residencia que se encuentra en el Caserío Xetinimit de la Aldea Nimasac, del departamento y municipio de Totonicapán, Guatemala,  actualmente, por las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra  no son suficientes para poder cubrir su necesidad, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención de comprar materia prima y de esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas, esperando también poder sacar adelante a su familia, y que tengan mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Lucia G., 31, is married and lives with her husband and children. She and her husband have been artisans for the last 12 years. They weave "Typical Aprons for Women" in their home, which is in the Xetinimit settlement in Nimasac village, in the department and municipality of Totonicapán, Guatemala. Because of her current economic situation, she is unable to cover basic expenses so she has called upon Asociación ASDIR to request financing to buy raw materials so that she can increase sales hoping, too, to advance her family and to have better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Jumoke

texts.en: Jumoke is an LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Jumoke is 50 years old. She is a widow with 4 children, her youngest 20 years old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. Jumoke sells Nigerian cooked foods to earn a living. She starts the preparation of her cooked foods daily at 4:30 a.m.  She is a hard working woman who believes so much that hard work pays. Jumoke is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 30,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Hanna

texts.en:
Hanna is 33 years old. She is married and has two children, who are both in school. She lives with them and her husband in a rented apartment in Axim, which is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the local people.

Hanna is a trader, dealing in clothing materials for both males and females. She buys the goods from Accra. She sells door-to-door in her community and treks to nearby communities to sell. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Nuevo Horizonte Group

texts.en:
The Nuevo Horizonte committee was founded just 7 months ago by women who wanted to improve their businesses and livelihoods and have access to the credit and entrepreneurship training services offered by the Fundacion Paraguaya. They joined several neighbors who also have businesses and have since been meeting every Sunday night to discuss business strategies and to support each other.  
On average, each woman receives 580,952 gs., which will be invested in the purchase of items to be sold in their respective commercial activities. 

Using credit from Fundacion Paraguaya, Silvia opened a small shop selling food. Her business has since attracted numerous clients and grown considerably. Silvia's income has increased concurrently and she uses the money to improve her family's quality of life. 

Herminia C. sells cosmetics. 

Olga M. runs a pool hall. 

Silvia O. sells food. 

Gloria M. sells haberdashery. 

Cristina E. sells empanadas. 

Margarita S. sells jewelry. 

Carmen R. collects and resells recycled materials. 

Norma B. sells Argentinian goods. 

Estela B. sells clothes, candy and plants. 

Severe P. sells food. 

Lourdes B. sells Argentinian goods. 

Estelvina Evans sells plants. 

Sandra B. sells clothes. 

Francisca M. sells food. 

Florentina C. sells charcoal. 

Esther R. sells clothes. 

Elvira M. is a seamstress. 

Casimira M. sells haberdashery. 

Marta R. sells plants. 

Teodora V. sells charcoal. 

Lilian B. sells lingerie.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Manuela Cristina

texts.es: Doña Manuela tiene 37 años D. edad, es Soltera D. oficios Artesana,  “Elaboración D. Cortes Típicos”, habita junto  a sus Papas, ella se dedica en la Artesanía, llevan  8  años D. Laborar,   su residencia que se encuentra en el Paraje  Chibatz del  Cantón Juchanep, del departamento y municipio D. Totonicapán, Guatemala,  actualmente la demanda D. su clientela a crecido, pero las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra no son suficientes para que ella  pueda aumentar su capital, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención D. comprar materia prima y D. esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas, esperando también poder sacar adelante a su familia, y que tengan mejores condiciones D. vida.
texts.en:
Manuela, 37, is single and she's an artisan. She makes typical clothing. She lives with her parents and has worked as an artisan for 8 years. Her home is in Paraje Chibatz, which is in the Juchanep territory of the department and municipality of Totonicapán, Guatemala. Demand for her products has grown recently but her economic conditions are such that she is unable to afford to increase her capital. For this reason, she has called upon Asociación ASDIR to request financing to buy raw materials so that she can increase sales thereby helping to get her family ahead in life and to have better living condiditons.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia is 37 years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all of whom are in school. She lives with them and her husband in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is along the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people there. 

Emilia is a trader. She runs a provisions store. Her store is by the roadside in her community. Emilia buys the goods from Accra. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure all kinds of provisions in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy provisions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is 28 years old. Her husband is a local football coach in Ibadan. She has three children and her youngest child is just 1 year old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. 

Comfort has a salon where she makes lovely hairstyles for her customers. She also sells hair extensions and cream. This is the high season for business and she hopes to make more profits. She is requesting a loan of 40,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr: A. Mariam est née le 25 Décembre 1979 au Bénin. Mariam est mariée à GANSSON Jules et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge. Mariam vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Aïdjèdo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a trois ans de cela que la famille vit dans ce quartier. C'est principalement le mari qui assure les charges de la famille. Cependant, Mariam vient en aide à son mari dans l'entretien et l'éducation des enfants. Mariam n'a pas été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Mariam vend de la nourriture (riz, akassa : aliment local fait à base d'amidon de maïs, accompagné de sauce, etc.)dans son quartier. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Mariam s'approvisionne. Mariam a trois ans d'expérience dans cette activité. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a bien remboursé les trois crédits qu'elle avait obtenu de l'institution. Dans le but d'agrandir son activité afin de mieux satisfaire la demande de la clientèle, Mariam sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Mariam was born on December 25, 1979 in Benin.  She is married to GANSSON Jules and is the mother of two children who are both in school.  The couple has another child in their care.  Mariam lives together with her children and husband in the Aïdjèdo district in  Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  The family has lived in this district for three years.  The husband is principally the one ensuring that family expenses are covered.  However, Mariam works in aid of her husband to educate and care for the children.  Mariam did not attend to school.  To address her needs, she sells food (rice; and akasssa, a local food made with cornstarch and served with sauce) in her district.   Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, is where she stocks up.  She has three years of experience in this business.  She is a previous ALIDé client who repaid the three loans she had obtained from this micro-finance institution.  With the goal of expanding her business in order to satisfy customer demands better, she's requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of rice, corn, cassava flour, and vegetable oil

loans.name: María Luisa

texts.es: Doña María R. tiene 64 años de edad, es Casada de oficios Artesana,  “Elaboración de Fajas Típicas”, habita junto  a sus Hijos, ella se dedica en la Artesanía, llevan  20  años de Laborar,   su residencia que se encuentra en el Paraje  Xecaja del  Cantón Poxlajuj, del departamento y municipio de Totonicapán, Guatemala,  actualmente la demanda de su clientela a crecido, pero las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra no son suficientes para que ella  pueda aumentar su capital, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención de comprar materia prima y de esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas, esperando también poder sacar adelante a su familia, y que tengan mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
María R., 64, is married and she's an artisan. She makes typical sashes. She lives with her children and she has been an artisan for 20 years. She lives in Paraje Xecaja which is in the Poxlajuj terriroty of the department and municipality of Totonicapán, Guatemala. Currently, demand for her creations has grown but her economic situation is such that she is unable to increase her capital. For this reason she has called upon Asociación ASDIR to request financing in order to buy raw materials to increase her sales thereby allowing her to move her family ahead in life and to have better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Abimbola Flora

texts.en: Flora is 43 years old and married to a contractor. They have four children. Flora is a hairstylist; she creates different styles of hair and sells hair accessories such as hair creams, hair extensions, nails etc. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She is a member of LAPO Microfinance.  Having been in LAPO for over two years now, she is requesting a loan in the amount of NGN 170,000 to expand her hair clinic by purchasing more hair accessories to sell and for styling hair.

loans.use: to purchase more hair extensions and hair accessories to sell

loans.name: Rosalinda Matea

texts.es: Doña Rosalinda R. tiene 30 años de edad, es Casada de oficios Artesana,  “Elaboración de Fajas Típicas”, habita junto  a sus Hijos, ella se dedica en la Artesanía, llevan  tiempo 8  años de Laborar,   su residencia que se encuentra en el Paraje  Xecaja del  Cantón Poxlajuj, del departamento y municipio de Totonicapán, Guatemala,  actualmente la demanda de su clientela a crecido, pero las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra no son suficientes para que ella  pueda aumentar su capital, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención de comprar materia prima y de esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas, esperando también poder sacar adelante a su familia, y que tengan mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Rosalinda R., 30, is married and she's an artisan. She makes typical sashes. She lives with her children and has been in this line of work for 8 years. She lives in Paraje Xecaja, which is in the Poxlajuj territory of the department and municipality of Totonicapán, Guatemala. Currently, demand for her wares has increased but her economic situation does not permit her to increase her capital. For this reason, she has called upon Asociación ASDIR to request financing to buy raw materials with which to increase her sales hoping, thereby, to help her family get ahead in life and to have better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Oluayo

texts.en:
Oluayo is 41 years old. He is married with 4 children, the eldest 12 years old. His children are still dependent on him and they go to school. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. His wife sells foodstuffs to support the home. Oluayo sells shoes to make a living. He has been in this business for a long time. This is the high season for business and he hopes to make more profit.

Oluayo is an LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. Oluayo is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more shoes to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen, 43 years old, is married and has three children who are all currently in school. Ellen lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a touristy coastal community in the central region of Ghana. The major occupation of the local people is fishing.

Ellen is a merchant. She runs a provisions store by the roadside in the community. She procures her goods from Accra. According to Ellen, she has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy provisions

loans.name: Abosede

texts.en: Abosede is 35 years of age, and married with three children. Her husband is a civil servant in Lagos. She sells drinks both wholesale and retail. She started this business 8 years ago in order to support her family in the little way she can by providing the basic necessities of life. She needs a loan amount of NGN 170,000 to purchase more drinks in larger quantities to sell. She believes that having an assortment of drinks will increase her sales. She says a big thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Pélagie

texts.fr: B. Pélagie est née en 1969 au Bénin. Pélagie est une divorcée, et mère de deux enfants. Les deux enfants sont scolarisés. Pélagie vit seule avec ses enfants à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Pélagie n'a pas été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Pélagie vend de la friperie au marché Houègbo et à Calavi, non loin de Cotonou. Pélagie s'approvisionne à Missèbo, un marché de friperies situé à Cotonou au Bénin. Pélagie a 10 ans d'expérience dans ce métier, et a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé. Pélagie a bien remboursé les deux crédits qu'elle a obtenus de ALIDé. Dans l'optique de rehausser davantage le niveau de son activité afin de se faire une épargne, Pélagie sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Pélagie B. was born in 1969 in Benin. Pélagie is a divorced mother of two children. Both children went to school. Pélagie lives alone with her children in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Pélagie did not go to school. To meet her needs, Pélagie sells used clothing at the Houègbo market and at Calavi, not far from Cotonou. Pélagie gets her supplies at Missèbo, the use clothing market located in Cotonou, Benin. Pélagie has 10 years of experience in this business, and has already received two loans from ALIDé. Pélagie repaid both loans that she received from ALIDé. In order to further increase her business activity for the purpose of accumulating some savings, Pélagie is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Bruce Popp, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing Bales of Used Clothing

loans.name: Sohada

texts.fr: Cette femme est une résidente du quartier d’agoè atsanvé, elle est une célibataire ; pour subvenir à ses propres besoins, elle a commencé en 1998 la vente de bouillie faite à base de farine de maïs. Ce commerce marche bien pour elle car beaucoup de personnes viennent déjeuner chez elle le matin. Actuellement les matières nécessaires à son activité sont épuisées, elle souhaiterait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un premier crédit pour acheter 2 sacs de maïs, 3 sacs de sucres, 2 sacs de mil et divers.
texts.en:
This woman lives in the Agoè Atsanvé neighborhood. She is unmarried. To meet her own needs, she started to sell cornmeal porridge in 1998. This business is going well because many people come to eat at her place in the morning. Currently the supplies needed for her business are exhausted and she would like to resupply. That is why she asked WAGES for her first loan to buy two sacks of corn, three sacks of sugar, two sacks of millet and various other things.

Translated from French by Bruce Popp, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Corn, Sugar and Other Supplies

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica is forty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to five children who are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing dominated community in the central region of Ghana. Veronica is a trader. She trades in infants’ layette – a set of clothing and accessories for a newborn baby. She hawks and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. Veronica has been in business for over ten years and would like to give her business a facelift. She therefore wants the loan to procure many kinds of layette in bulk to achieve this dream.

loans.use: To buy children’s wear.

loans.name: Rosario Cristina

texts.es: Doña Rosario R. tiene 25 años de edad, es Casada de oficios Comerciante,  “Venta de Cortes Típicos”, habita junto  a sus Papas, ella se dedica en el Comercio, llevan  6  años de Vender,   su residencia que se encuentra en el Paraje  Xecaja del  Cantón Poxlajuj, del departamento y municipio de Totonicapán, Guatemala,  actualmente la demanda de su clientela a crecido, pero las condiciones económicas en que se encuentra no son suficientes para que ella  pueda aumentar su capital, por tal razón acudió a la Asociación ASDIR, a solicitar un préstamo, con la intención de comprar más Mercadería y de esa manera poder aumentar sus ventas, esperando también poder sacar adelante a su familia, y que tengan mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Rosario R., 25, is married and is a merchant. She has sold typical clothing tor 6 years. She lives with her parents in Paraje Xecaja which is in the Poxlajuj territory of the department and municipality of Totonicapán, Guatemala. Currently, demand for her products has grown but her economic conditions have not allowed her to increase her capital. For this reason, she has called upon Asociación ASDIR to request financing in order to buy more stock items so that her sales will increase hoping, thereby, to help her family get ahead in life and to have better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Christian

texts.en: Christian is forty-three. She is married and a mother of three children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in one of the tourist attraction centres in Ghana. Since the community is a coastal town in the region, the majority of the inhabitants are fishermen/women. Christian is a hairdresser by profession. She has her workshop on one of the streets and has five apprentices who are currently under training. She says she has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy artificial hair and other working materials to be able to render better services to her valued clients.

loans.use: To buy artificial hair.

loans.name: Isidora

texts.es:
La señora ISIDORA C. J. tiene 53 años, vive en el distrito deL PORVENIR, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal CARIDAD II. La socia presenta estudios  hasta 5to de primaria, refiere que es de la sierra y que desde pequeña se dedicó a trabajar, por ese motivo no continuó sus estudios; es conviviente  y tiene 5 hijos de los cuales 2 dependen económicamente de ella. La socia se dedica a la crianza de pollos para su posterior comercialización, también se dedica a la confeccion de ropa para caballeros, damas y niños.
Con su primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles, compró pollos bebes los cuales vendió.
Con este crédito de 500.00 nuevos soles, comprará pollos y alimento balanceado al por mayor. Ella sueña con aumentar la crianza de sus pollos.
texts.en:
Miss ISIDORA C. J. is 53 years old, she lives in the EL PORVENIR district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department in Peru. She belongs to the Communal Bank CARIDAD II. The member has a 5th grade primary school education, she is from the mountain and since she was little she started working, which is why she didn't finish studying. Isidora is cohabiting and has 5 children, 2 of whom are still economically dependent. This member is dedicated to raising chickens and manufacturing clothing for gentlemen, ladies and kids. With her first credit of 300.00 new soles, she purchased baby chickens whom she sold. With this credit of 500.00 new soles she will purchase chickens and wholesale chicken food. She dreams of increase her chicken raising.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PURCHASE CHICKENS AND WHOLESALE CHICKEN FOOD

loans.name: Zounkpa

texts.fr: D. Zounkpa est née en 1969 et réside depuis une dizaine d'année à Sainte Cécile, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à HOUSSOU Hounyè, Zounkpa est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Zounkpa vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Zounkpa n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Zounkpa vend de l'huile de palme à Cotonou. C'est à Zinvié à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, que Zounkpa fait ses approvisionnements. Zounkpa a déjà 10 ans d'expérience dans ce métier. Zounkpa est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de l'institution, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Zounkpa voudrait agrandir davantage son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C'est la raison pour laquelle Zounkpa sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Zounkpa D. was born in 1969 and for the past decade or so she has lived in Sainte Cécile, a neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Hounyè Houssou, and she is the mother of three children, all of whom are in school. Zounkpa helps her husband with the family expenses. Zounkpa did not go to school. To cover her own costs, those of her husband, and those of her children, Zounkpa sells palm oil at Cotonou. She gets her provisions at Zinvié, in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Zounkpa has 10 years of experience with this work. She is a past client of ALIDé, and has already taken out two loans with this organization. These loans have been paid off properly. Zounkpa would like to continue to grow her business and better meet the needs of her clients. This is the reason why Zounkpa is asking for a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cans of palm oil

loans.name: Foussena

texts.fr: Cette jeune dame exerce comme commerce la vente de beignets qui est préparé à base de farine de maïs et  d’huile végétale et qui est très apprécié  par les togolais. Mais actuellement les matières entrant dans la préparation des beignets sont épuisées, pour se réapprovisionner elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 6 sacs maïs, 5 bidons  d’huile et divers.
texts.en:
This young woman has a business selling beignets (doughnuts) which are prepared from a base of flour, corn, and vegetable oil, and which are a favourite of people from Togo. However, currently her ingredients for the preparation of beignets have run out. In order to reprovision herself, she is asking for a loan from WAGES to buy 6 sacks of corn, 5 cans of oil, and various other things.

Translated from French by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of beans, cans of oil, and various other things

loans.name: Lucina Miliana

texts.es:
La señora LUCINA MILIANA tiene 44 años, vive en el distrito de Trujillo, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal MUJERES AL ÉXITO II. La socia presenta estudios superiores de educación (incompletos), refiere que por falta de recursos económicos no pudo continuar estudiando. Es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos de los cuales 1 depende económicamente de ella. La socia se dedica a la crianza y venta de pollos vivos y por kilos. El primer crédito de 300.00 nuevos soles, lo utilizó para comprar pollos bebes y alimento balanceado al por mayor.
Con este crédito de 400.00 nuevos soles lo utilizará para comprar pollos, patos y alimento balanceado al por mayor. Ella sueña con tener una granja de pollos.
texts.en:
Miss LUCINA MILIANA is 44 years old, she lives in the Trujillo district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department – Perú. She belongs to the Communal Bank of MUJERES AL ÉXITO II (WOMEN TO SUCCESS). The partner presents incomplete higher education studies, she could not continue studying due to lack of economical resources. She is a single mother of two children, one of whom is still economically dependant. This member is dedicated to raising and selling chickens (both alive and by kilograms). She used her first credit of 300.00 new soles to purchase baby chickens and wholesale balanced chicken food. With this credit of 400.00 new soles she will purchasse chickens, ducks and wholesale balanced chicken and duck food. She dreams of having a chicken farm

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PURCHASE CHICKEN, DUCKS AND WHOLESALE CHICKEN AND DUCK FOOD

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is 40 years old. She is married with 2 children and her youngest child is 9 years old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She sells sarongs and lace at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more sarongs and lace to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and lace to sell.

loans.name: San Rafael Group

texts.es:
SAN RAFAEL es un comité  que se encuentra en pleno desarrollo de la décimo etapa del Proyecto Mujeres Emprendedoras  dentro de la Fundación Paraguaya cuenta con 19 integrantes. 
Todas las integrantes son mujeres muy sacrificadas y luchadoras cada una con una familia que sacar adelante.
Se puede mencionar  el caso de la Sra . Juliana V.  posee un pequeño puesto de venta de frutas al costado de la Avda.  Carreteras de López, ella va al mercado de abasto a comprar las frutas,  ademas vende también  jugos naturales, tiene clientela  formada y asegurada ya que sus productos son muy solicitados. Con el ingreso que ella consigue día a día ayuda al marido. La misma comento que ingreso en el comité con la idea de ampliar su pequeño negocio y actualmente lo esta logrando por ello agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya.
Es un comité antiguo pero con  muchas ganas de superarse.
texts.en:
San Rafael is a committee of the Mujeres Emprendedoras [Enterprising Women] program of Fundación Paraguaya. This is their tenth loan. The committee has 19 members. All of them are sacrificing and fighting women, each with a family to raise.

It bears mentioning the case of Mrs. Juliana V., who has small fruit stand on Carreteras de López Avenue. She goes to the wholesale food market to buy fruit. She also sells natural juices. She has a regular and assured client base, as her products are much in demand. With the income that she makes day-by-day, she helps out her husband.

Juliana comments that she entered the committee with the idea of building her small business, and now she is achieving that goal. For that, she is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya. The committee is old, but is working hard to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Merchandise, clothing, fruit, herbs, cloth, cleaning products, and food ingredients, all for retail sale.

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Clementine is 18 years old and is married but she doesn’t have a child. She lives with her husband in the Northern Province of Rwanda approximately three hours drive from Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.

Clementine employs one person from her community as a helper in her retail business selling different kinds of products such as salt, sugar, soap and other cosmetics goods, biscuits and so on. She has been in the business for two years and works from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Before this business activity Clementine was a full-time housewife. In that situation she could not help her husband to support her family because she hadn’t any income. After becoming a businesswoman she is able to earn a monthly profit of 30,000 RWF (approximately 50 USD).

Clementine is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to grow her business through purchasing more products such as salt, sugar, rice and shoes.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, sugar, salt and shoes for sale

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy is thirty-four years old. She is married and has given birth to four children who are all in school. She lives with her family in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Dorothy works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She trades in fresh fish. She buys directly from the fishermen in her community and supplies to other retailers and food vendors. Dorothy has been in business for over ten years and yearns to increase her stock. It is her desire to give all of her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther A. is married and has four children. She has completed junior high school. Esther sells gari, maize, and groundnuts at Teterem near Elmina, which she has been doing since 2004. Her husband is a plumber. Esther uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Esther will use the loan to purchase gari, maize, groundnuts and other food supplies for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esther plans to use it to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase gari, maize, groundnuts and other food supplies for sale.

loans.name: C2691 Amizero Group

texts.en:
Chantal is the group representative of a group composed of four people who have different kinds of business.
 
Chantal is 28 years old and is married with two children who are twins, seven years old. She also takes care of three dependents from her family, aged between 8 and 12. This big family lives in the Eastern Province of Rwanda, approximately two hours drive from Kigali, the capital city.

Chantal is a self-employed businesswoman selling foodstuffs such as rice, beans, flour, etc. She has been in this business for seven years and works from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Chantal is requesting her first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to reinvest in her business. She will use the loan to purchase more quantities of foodstuffs which will allow her to attract more customers.

If this strategy is successful Chantal will be able to earn more profits which will help her to achieve her family goals to save money for her future and pay school fees for her children and her dependents.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba is a sixty year old married mother of four children, some of whom are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Aba, like many other women in the community, works to support her husband to provide for the family. She trades in maize. She buys bags of maize from nearby farming communities and supplies to food vendors in her community. She has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize in bulk so she can supply to more customers to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize.

loans.name: Habibemi

texts.en: Habibemi is 47 years old and married with three children. She is a focused, hard worker. She sells cement. She wants to add sales of drums and minerals to her business in order to increase her profit. She is therefore requesting a loan amount of NGN 140,000 to purchase drums and minerals to sell. She hopes that this loan will help build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase drums and minerals to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is fifty-six years old. She is divorced but a mother of three children, some of whom are still in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Grace works very hard to be able to provide for the family. She is a trader in beef. She buys the beef from nearby towns and sells on a table top at the market square in her community. She also supplies to food vendors in her community. Grace has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk so she can supply to more customers to increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy beef.

loans.name: Madinatou

texts.fr: H. Madinatou est née en 1978 au Bénin. Madinatou vit depuis près de 15 ans à Hindé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à KOUKPAKI François, Madinatou est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Madinatou vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de leurs enfants. C'est principalement le mari qui assure les charges de la famille ; cependant, Madinatou vient en aide à son mari dans l'entretien et l'éducation des enfants. Madinatou n'a pas été à l'école, mais a appris la coiffure. Madinatou exerce cette activité depuis plus de 5 ans. A côté de cette activité, Madinatou vend des mèches, des produits cosmétiques et divers autres articles dont les bombons, etc. dans son atelier à Hindé. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Madinatou s'approvisionne. Madinatou a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. En vue de renforcer davantage son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Madinatou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Madinatou H. was born in 1978 in Benin. Madinatou has been living in the Hindé area of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital, for 15 years. Married to François KOUKPAKI, Madinatou is a mother of two children. They both attend school. Madinatou lives together with her children and her husband. The couple provides for another child in addition to their own. The husband is the main provider for the family; however, Madinatou assists her husband in the care and education of the children. Madinatou did not go to school, but she learned hairdressing. Madinatou has been in this business for over 5 years. Aside from this business, Madinatou sells hair extensions, cosmetics and various other items (incl. confectionery) in her studio in Hindé. Madinatou gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin's International market. Madinatou has already been granted two loans from ALIDé and paid them back without incident. Madinatou is requesting a third loan from ALIDé with the objective of reinforcing her activity and increasing her customers' satisfaction.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hair extension and cosmetic supplies.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is sixty years of age. She is divorced and the mother of two children who are both in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a tourist attraction community in the central region of Ghana. The community is one of the coastal towns in Ghana. As a result, the major occupation of the people is mainly fishing. Mary is a trader. She runs a provision store by the roadside in the community. She procures her goods from Accra. According to Mary, she has been in business for over thirty-five years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy provisions.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is fifty-two years of age. She is married and has given birth to three children who are all currently in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a tourist attraction community in the central region of Ghana. The community is one of the coastal towns in Ghana. As a result, the major occupation of the people is mainly farming. Victoria is a trader. She trades in all kinds of vegetable cooking oil, and supplies to other retailers and food vendors in her community. She procures her goods from nearby towns. According to Victoria, she has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil.

loans.name: Yadira Del Socorro

texts.es:
En el departamento de León, la señora Yadira C. tiene su propio establecimiento de venta de bebidas como jugos, gaseosas y agua de botella. Estos productos son ofrecidos por  ella misma a diario desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana hasta el atardecer.

El negocio tiene 15 años de existencia y es importante señalar que ella inició con pocos productos a la venta pero a medida que se ha venido desarrollando, ha mejorado sus condiciones de vida y la de su negocio.

Ella se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos anteriores que le ha brindado Ceprodel porque los ha utilizado en la compra de los productos y estos le han generado utilidades los cuales le han servido mucho para pagar los estudios de sus dos hijos ya que ella es madre soltera.
El crédito que solicita actualmente es para la compra de las bebidas jugos, gaseosas y agua para continuar ofreciéndolas en su localidad.
texts.en:
Yadira C. sells beverages like juices, soft-drinks and bottled water from her establishment in the department of León. She, herself, tends to her sales daily from very early in the morning until nightfall. She has been in this line of work for 15 years and it's important to point out that she began with just a few products in her inventory but, as she has been developing, both her business and her living conditions have improved. She is very satisfied with the loans that Ceprodel has approved for her in the past because she has used them to buy products and they have generated profits that she has been able to use to pay for her two children's schooling; she is a single mother. The financing requested on this occasion will be used to buy juices, soft-drinks, and bottled water in order to continue to offer them for sale in her location.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beverages.

loans.name: Gonzalo Angel

texts.en:
Gonzalo Angel O. C. is 47 years old and lives in a cane home in the Isla Trinitaria zone of Guayaquil. Mr. O. has sold merchandise on the streets of Guayaquil for over 10 years. From 8 am to 7 pm, Mr. O. sells kites, books, and temporal holiday merchandise. 

Beginning in August of every calendar year, Mr. O. creates “años viejos”.  Años viejos are effigies made of paper mache representing local and international politicians, famous celebrities, or even cartoon characters. At midnight on New Year`s Eve in Ecuador, the años viejos are burned in order to get rid of all the bad spirits from the previous year.

Mr. O. and his wife have 4 children ages 21, 20, 18 and 16; only the 16 and 18 year olds still live at home and attend public high school.  

Mr. O. is requesting a loan to buy Christmas hats ($300 worth), books, kites and paint for the años viejos ($200 worth). In the future, he hopes to fix the roof, walls and flooring of his home.

loans.use: To buy Christmas hats, books, kites and paint to sell.

loans.name: Shirley Adriana

texts.es:
Shirley R. de 25 años, vive en la zona Perimetral de Guayaquil,vive en uno de los pocos sectores que tiene la facilidad de contar con agua, luz y alcantarillado,  el negocio de la vulcanizadora lo comenzó su papa y sus hermanos quienes con esfuerzo y dedicación pudieron sacarlo adelante, ahora Shirley lo administra.

Shirley hace las compras de las llantas grandes a $ 25.00 y las vende a  $ 40.00 y las llantas pequeñas a $ 6.00 y las vende a $ 12.00 las dificultades que tiene es en la transportación de las llantas por los ladrones y el arrendador ya que le molesta la bulla de las maquinas, el esposo la ayuda en los gastos de la casa realizando la actividad de pegar mármol en ciudadelas, no tienen hijos pero para poder tener mas grande su familia Shirley desea estar estable en una casa y no alquilarla.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar más llantas y tubos unos 950 para agrandar el negocio, en el futuro quiere poner otra vulcanizadota y en mucho mas tiempo poner un estudio fotográfico ya que Shirley sabe de esta actividad pero no ha podido por la situación económica de su familia.
texts.en:
Shirley R., 25, lives in the Perimetral area of Guayaquil. She lives in one of the few areas that has water, light, and sewage services. Her father started the tire repair shop, and through much effort her siblings have been able to succeed with it. Now, Shirley manages it. Shirley buys large tires for $25.00, and sells them for $40.00. She buys small tires for $6.00, and sells them for $12.00. The difficulties she has are thieves when she transports the tires, and the landlord is bothered by the noise from the machines. Her husband helps her with the household expenses. He works installing marble in gated communities. They do not have children. But, in order to be able to have a larger family Shirley wants to be stable in a house and not rent one. She wants to use the loan to buy more tires and pipes, 950, in order to expand her business. In the future she would like to set up another tire repair shop. In the distant future she would like to have a photography studio because Shirley knows this work. She has not been able to do it because of the economic situation of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tires and pipes for cars

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is fifty-seven years old. She is divorced and has given birth to three children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing dominated community in the central region of Ghana. Elizabeth is a trader in printed fabrics. She hawks and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. Elizabeth has been in business for over twenty years and would like to give her business a facelift. She therefore wants the loan to procure many kinds of printed fabrics in bulk to achieve this dream.

loans.use: To buy printed fabrics.

loans.name: Samuel Onorio

texts.es:
Samuel C. de 40 años, vive en la zona Perimetral de Guayaquil, vive en uno de los pocos sectores que tiene agua, alcantarillado, camino pavimentado y luz, su casa es de cemento, la historia del negocio de Samuel empezó cuando comenzó a trabajar como oficial de cerrajería y pudo aprender muchas cosas como soldador por motivos de la falta de ingresos en su familia tubo que continuar con esta actividad. 

Samuel empieza constantemente armando y soldando hierro desde las 08h00 hasta las 17h00, comprar hierro por $ 1.000.00 y los vende a $ 1.500.00 algunas de las dificultades de su trabajo es la transportación del hierro, Samuel esta en unión libre con su pareja  la que tiene como actividad los quehaceres domésticos, con su pareja tiene 3 niños uno de 6 años, otro de 8 años los cuales estudian en una escuela fiscal y otro de 14 años que estudia en un colegio fiscal.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar mas hierro para poder así agrandar el negocio, en el futuro quiere poner otro negocio para tener tiempo para estudiar a sus hijos y aprender de ellos y también le ayudaría a tener estabilidad económica y salud.
texts.en:
Samuel C., 40, lives in the outskirts of Guayaquil in one of the few area that has water, drainage, paved streets, and electricity. His house is concrete. He began his work history working as a locksmith. There, he learned many things including welding skills. Due to his family's low income, he has had to continue with this line of work. He works welding iron from 8am until 5pm. He buys iron at $1,000 and sells it at $1500. One of the difficult things about his job is transporting the iron. Samuel is in a common-law relationship with his wife, who is a housewife. They have three children, an 8-year-old and a 6-year-old, who are in public elementary school, and a 14-year-old, who is in public secondary school. With the funding he will buy more iron in order to enlarge his business. In the future, he would like to set up a different business so that he can have time to study his children and learn from them and also help to have better economic stability and health.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy iron.

loans.name: Yeadze

texts.en: Yeadze is twenty-nine years old. She is married has given birth to one child who is in school. She lives with her husband and son in a rented apartment in a fishing dominated community in the central region of Ghana. Yeadze is a trader in jewelry. She hawks and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. Yeadze has been in business for three years and would like to expand her business. She wants the loan to procure many kinds of jewelry – earrings, necklace, etc. in bulk.

loans.use: To buy jewelry.

loans.name: Zhanny Nuve

texts.es:
Zhanny Zuñay de 43 años, tiene una casa de cemento con la que cuenta con agua, luz, alcantarillado y caminos pavimentados es uno de los pocos sectores que tiene esta facilidades esta ubicada en la zona Perimetral de Guayaquil, Zhanny empezó con esfuerzo y dedicación con su negocio hace 6 años atrás, cuando escogió poner un bazar en su casa para pasar tiempo con sus 2 hijas.

Zhanny trabaja desde las 08h00 hasta las 21h00 en la cual su hija de 13 años le ayuda a atender el negocio, Zhanny comprar helados a $ 0.30 y los vende a $ 0.50 c/u, cuadernos a $0.70 y los vende $ 1.20 c/u y confites a $ 0.10 y los vende a $ 0.15, aunque una de las dificultades mas importantes es cuando se enferma aunque es muy rara la vez aun así sigue adelante, su esposo le ayuda con los gastos de la familia siendo vendedor ambulante de helados pero aun así su situación económica no es estable ya que su hija de 4 años no estudia y su hija de 13 años estudia en un colegio particular y esta becada.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar $300.00 en helados y $200.00 en confites para surtirlo mas, su meta en un futuro es agrandar su negocio y así poder arreglar su vivienda que aun le falta enlucir y hacer el cerramiento también poder ver que su hija se gradúe del Colegio.
texts.en:
Zhanny Zuñay, 43, has a house made of concrete in one of the few areas in the outskirts of Guayaquil that has running water, electricity, drainage, and paved streets. Six years ago she decided to set up a store in her home so that she could have time to spend with her two daughters. She works from 8am until 9pm; her 13-year-old daughter helps her with the store. Zhanny buys frozen treats at $0.30 and she sells them at $0.50 each; notebooks at $0.70 and sells them at $1.20 each and sweets at $0.10 that she sells at $0.15. One of her obstacles is when she gets sick, although this is rare, she has to go on. Her husband helps with household expenses; he's an ice-cream peddler, but even so her economic situation is unstable. Her 4-year-old isn't in school yet and her 13-year-old is in private school, but on scholarship. With the funding she wants to buy $300 worth of frozen treats and $200 worth of sweets. Her goal for the future is to enlarge her business so that she can improve her house, which still needs lighting and fencing. She would also like to see her daughter graduate from secondary school.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Frozen treats and sweets.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Nuestra socia MERCEDES tiene 37 años y trabaja como recepcionista en una agencia de viajes y domina los idiomas de Ingles, francés, castellano y quechua. La socia se ingenio para abrir un pequeño negocio de venta de boletos de ingreso para el centro arqueológicos de Machupicchu. La socia compra de la oficina “boleto turístico” los ticket y después en la agencia de viajes lo vende a los turistas que llegan a la ciudad del Cusco, cuyas ganancias aporta al ingreso económico en su hogar. La socia tiene una fuerza de voluntad única para seguir adelante pues ahora emprendió un nuevo negocio de venta de refrigerios. Ya son varios años con la venta de entradas y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia a pesar de las adversidades. La socia requiere el préstamo para adquirir más boletos de ingreso al centro arqueológico de Machupicchu.   

La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “HUAYNA CCAPAC” de la Asociación Arariwa de la Provincia del Cusco del Departamento del Cusco.   

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
MERCEDES, 37, speaks English, French, Spanish and Quechua and works as a receptionist in a travel agency. She figured out a way to start a small business selling entry tickets to the Machupicchu archaelogical site. She buys the tickets from the "Tourist Ticket" office and then sells them to tourists who come into the travel agency in the city of Cusco. Profits from these sales go to her household expenses. She has a unique, strong will to get ahead because now she has started a new line of work: she sells refreshments. She has sold the entry tickets for several years now and has done well thanks to the effort she puts into her work. She is a hard-working, enterprising woman who struggles to get her family ahead in life despite adversities. She needs funding to buy more entry tickets to the Machupicchu archaelogical site. She is a member of Asociación Arariwa's 'HUAYNA CCAPAC" communal bank, which is in Cusco province, Cusco department. She is grateful for the opportunity provided by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy entry tickets to the Machupicchu archaeological site to resell to tourists.

loans.name: Lorena Del Carmen

texts.es:
Lorena M. de 48 años, vive en uno de los pocos sectores que tiene la facilidad de contar con agua, luz y alcantarillado todavía el camino de su casa no esta pavimentado su ubicación es en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, Lorena empezó hace 4 años vendiendo Yanbal por medio de una amiga que la animo a vender cosméticos y así tener una entrada de dinero para su familia.
 
Lorena trabaja de las 14:00 hasta las 18h00 vendiendo cosméticos y perfumes, comprar mensualmente un total de $ 280.00 en cosméticos y los vende sacando $ 400.00 mensual, ayudándole también su hija de 16 años a vender cosméticos y perfumes.

El esposo de Lorena le ayuda con los gastos familiares vendiendo frutas ellos tienen 4 hijos, uno de 29 años otro de 24 años otro de 19 años y la menor de sus hijas tiene 16 años quien estudia en un colegio fiscal.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar mas cosméticos para poder agrandar su negocio en su casa, en el futuro Lorena quiere arreglar su domicilio y tener más variedad en su mercadería.
texts.en:
Lorena M., 48, lives in one of the few sectors of the outskirts of Guayaquil that has running water, electricity and drainage. The street where she lives isn't paved yet. Four years ago Lorena began selling Yanbal (a brand of catalogue cosmetics) thanks to a girlfriend who encouraged her to do so in order to have a source of income for her family. She works from 2pm until 6pm selling cosmetics and perfumes. She buys $280 worth of cosmetics per month and she sells them for $400 per month. Her 16-year-old daughter helps her sell. Lorena's husband helps out with household expenses; he's a fruit merchant. They have four children, a 29-year-old, a 24-year-old, a 19-year-old and their youngest daughter, 16, who is in public secondary school. She will use the financing to buy cosmetics so that she can enlarge her business in her home. In the future, Lorena would like to improve her home and have a larger variety of stock merchandise available.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cosmetics, perfumes.

loans.name: Brian

texts.en: Brian definitely has an entrepreneurial streak - after converting a city bus to run on vegetable oil, he launched his own alternative fuel retail company at the tender age of 23, right after getting his engineering degree. Brian recognizes that alternative fuel methods, while in demand, are costly for the average consumer, and his idea was to sell affordable products to meet this demand. Brian started his business on Ebay (an online buying and selling organization), where it was very successful. In the summer of 2008, shortly after he began selling, world oil prices took off and Brian's business became wildly profitable. He now has three very busy employees and keeps costs down by ordering in bulk, so that he can keep shipping costs affordable for his customers. He's going to use this loan to purchase inventory so that he can stay ahead of the curve in meeting his customers’ demands - as he says, "if I run out, it's an emergency!" Aware of his participation in the "green" movement, Brian is convinced that renewable energy is "the fuel of the future" because "unlike everything else, it won't run out at some point." Though Brian wants to stay on the cutting edge in terms of designing innovative renewable energy products, he always keeps an eye towards his customers and makes sure to continue offering the products they want. Brian hopes that one day, he can run a biodiesel station on the highway that will be affordable enough to entice the average driver away from the gas station. About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA: Have you ever thought about how the cute new café on your corner or the salon you frequent every month got the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated ten million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis”. Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education. Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To increase his inventory of alternative fuel and chemicals

loans.name: Awo

texts.en: Awo is forty years of age. She is widowed and has given birth to two children who are both currently in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a tourist attraction community in the central region of Ghana. The community is one of the coastal towns in Ghana. As a result, the occupation of the people is mainly farming. Awo is a trader in coconut cooking oil. She supplies to other retailers and food vendors in her community. Awo procures the oil from nearby towns. According to her, she has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy cooking oil in large quantities so she can supply to more customers.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro came to the U.S. from Colombia in 2003 with his wife. In the beginning, he was working very long hours, and the pay wasn't enough to justify keeping him away from his family for so long - in fact, he says, it wasn't even enough to support his family. That's when he had the idea to import handmade crafts from his home country and sell them in Miami. Pedro says that the accessories he imports were not well-known in Miami before he started importing them, but he has been successful in selling them. His wife chooses the inventory and gets the best deal possible, and he sells it to responsible distributors in Miami and other metro areas such as NY, LA, Houston, and Atlanta.

Pedro will use this loan to increase his inventory, and he says that clients have requested more products that he does not have at the moment. He says the loan will also help him increase his inventory in preparation for increased demand during the holiday season. In the future, he hopes to start importing items from other countries, such as Peru and Mexico, directly from the local craftsmen and women who make them.

About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA

Have you ever thought about how the cute new café on your corner or the salon you frequent every month got the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated 10 million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis.” Microfinance institutions like ACCION USA support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education.

Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: Buying and diversifying inventory

loans.name: Grecia Jaqueline

texts.es:
Grecia A. de 35 años, tiene una casa de caña ubicada en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, Grecia empezó trabajando en un almacén de ropa en el cual no le cancelaban puntualmente la mensualidad gracias a este inconveniente pensó una nueva forma de trabajar para seguir ayudando a su familia, y tomo el rumbo de comenzar vendiendo ropa ella misma de puerta en puerta.

Ahora Grecia compra en los almacenes pantalones y blusas a $ 8.00 y los vende a $ 16.00 c/u, interiores a $ 0.75 y los vende a $ 1.25 c/u  con ayuda del catalogo de ropa, algunas de las complicaciones es cuando los clientes no les cancelan a tiempo y por eso la detienen para volver a comprar mas mercadería.

Grecia no esta casado pero con esfuerzo y dedicación a podido seguir adelante con sus 4 hijos que estudian en un colegio Fiscal.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar $ 100.00 de ropa para poder agrandar su negocio, y en el futuro Grecia quiere construir su casa la que actualmente es de caña y poderle dar un mejor futuro para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Grecia A. is 35 years old and lives in a stick home located in the outskirts of Guayaquil. Grecia began working in a clothing warehouse where orders were not always cancelled in time. Thanks to this inconvenience, she came up with a new way to work in order to be able to continue helping her family. She began selling clothing form door to door. Now Grecia buys pants and shirts through catalogs from warehouses for $8 and sells them for $16, underwear for $0.75 and sells them for $1.25. Sometimes she has some problems because customers do not always cancel orders in time, which reduces her ability to buy additional inventory. Grecia is not married but her effort and dedication has allowed her to move ahead with her four children who are in school. She wants to use the money from this loan to buy $100 worth of clothes in order to grow her business. In the future, Grecia would like to build a new home and give a better life to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing for resale

loans.name: Moussouaboua

texts.fr: Marié et père de 05 enfants, ce monsieur pour subvenir aux charges de ses enfants a ouvert en 1998 sa propre boutique qu’il a appelé « LA PAIX N°2 », il est  très connu dans son quartier à cause de son dynamisme. Les périodes de fêtes de fin d’année étant proche, il voudrait en profiter au maximun et sollicite par donc de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 20 sacs de riz, 10 bidons d’huile, 10 cartons de spaghetti et divers. Avec l’expérience qu’il a dans ce commerce il compte rentabiliser le crédit qu’il a obtenu.
texts.en:
Married and a father of five, this gentleman opened his own shop in 1998 to help support his children. He called the shop "PEACE #2". He is renowned in his neighborhood for his dynamism. He would like to make the most of the imminent holiday season; therefore he is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase 20 bags of rice, 10 barrels of oil, 10 cases of spaghetti and other assorted goods. He trusts that with his experience in this type of retail he will be able to use the loan to turn a profit.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase bags of rice, cans of oil and spaghetti boxes

loans.name: Kofi

texts.en: Kofi is twenty-nine years of age. He is single and has no children. He lives alone in a rented apartment in a tourist attraction community in the central region of Ghana. The community is one of the coastal towns in Ghana. As a result, the occupation of the people is mainly farming. Kofi deals in herbal and scientific medicines. He sells them in a shop by the roadside in his community. Kofi has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase his stock.

loans.use: To buy medicine.

loans.name: Frida Nurmi

texts.es:
Nuestra socia FRIDA tiene 47 años es una madre soltera que tiene 4 hijos. Tres D. sus hijos estudian en la universidad y uno ya es independiente. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con la atención D. su tienda D. ferretería donD. venD. pernos y clavos, tuercas, tornillos, etc. cuyas ganancias aporta al ingreso económico en su hogar. La socia tiene una fuerza D. voluntad única para seguir adelante pues esta sacando profesionales a sus cuatro hijos. La socia nos cuenta que su hijo Juan estudia la carrera profesional D. Ingeniería D. Sistemas en la prestigiosa Universidad Nacional San Antonio Abad del Cusco. 
Ya son varios años que tiene el negocio D. la ferretería y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia a pesar D. no contar con el apoyo D. su ex pareja, el padre D. sus cuatro hijos. La socia requiere el préstamo para adquirir más mercadería como clavos y tuercas.      

La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “HUAYNA CCAPAC” D. la Asociación Arariwa D. la Provincia del Cusco del Departamento del Cusco.   

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
FRIDA, 47, is a single mother of 4 children, three of whom are university students, one already independent. She alternates her domestic activities with tending to her hardware store where she sells bolts, nails, screws, nuts, etc. Profits from the shop go towards household expenses. She has a strong will to get ahead in life and is succeeding in seeing her four children become professionals. She tells us that her son Juan is majoring in Systems Engineering at the prestigious San Antonio Abad del Cusco National University. She has had her hardware store for several years now and has done well thanks to all the effort she puts into her work. She is a hard-working, enterprising mother who struggles to get her family ahead in life despite not getting any help from her ex-husband, the father of her four children. She needs financing to buy stock materials like nails and nuts. She is a member of Asociación Arariwa's "HUAYNA CCAPAC" communal bank, which is in Cusco province, Cusco department. She is grateful for the opportunity offered by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more merchandise like nails and screws.

loans.name: Djobo

texts.fr: Ce monsieur s’est lancé en 2008 dans le commerce  de sacs de riz, il dispose d’une grande clientèle. Beaucoup de propriétaire de restaurant viennent s’approvisionner chez lui. La demande de ces derniers jours est assez forte à cause des fêtes de fin d’année, il veut s’approvisionner pour répondre à la demande de ses clients raison pour laquelle  il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 30 sacs de riz et commencer le commerce de boissons avec 30 cartons de boissons et divers
texts.en:
In 2008, this gentleman got started in the commerce of rice.  He has a large customer base.  Many restaurant owners come to him to stock up.  The demand over these last few days is fairly strong due to the year-end holidays.  He wants to resupply himself to respond to the demands of his customers.  For these reasons, he's requesting from WAGES his first loan to buy 30 sacks of rice and to start selling beverages with 30 boxes of drinks and various other items. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of rice, boxes of canned drinks, and more

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida O. is married and has three children. She has received a senior high education. Vida owns a beauty salon and also sells provisions such as Milo, milk, sugar biscuits at Teterem near Elmina, which she has been doing since 2000. Her husband is an electronics dealer. Vida uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Vida will use the loan to buy more hair products to be used at the beauty salon and provisions for sale at her gocery store. With the new profits from her expanded business, Vida plans to use it to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more hair products for her beauty salon and provisions for sale at her gocery store.

loans.name: Vidjrakou

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de condiments plus précisément des  tomates et de piments verts, une partie de son stock de marchandises est avariée ; elle doit vite se réapprovisionner au risque de tomber en rupture de stock, elle demande donc à WAGES  un crédit pour se réapprovisionner avec  10 paniers de tomates et 6 sacs de piments verts.
texts.en:
This lady has a business selling condiments, that is, tomatoes and green chili peppers to be exact.  Part of her stock of goods is damaged;  she must quickly stock up again or run the risk of shortages.  She's therefore asking WAGES for a loan to resupply herself with 10 baskets of tomatoes and 6 sacks of green chilis.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying tomatoes and green chili peppers

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Nuestra socia LUCILA tiene 30 años es una madre soltera que tiene dos hijos. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con su trabajo como promotora de venta “Master Food”. La socia con en el carácter y el anhelo que le caracteriza abrió su propio negocio de ventas de joyas.  La socia tiene una fuerza de voluntad única para seguir adelante y va sacar profesionales a sus dos hijos. Ya son varios años que tiene el negocio de venta de joyas y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia a pesar de no contar con el apoyo de su ex pareja, el padre de sus dos hijos. La socia requiere el préstamo para adquirir más mercadería como pulseras, aretes, anillos y collares.           

La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal “HUAYNA CCAPAC” de la Asociación Arariwa de la Provincia del Cusco del Departamento del Cusco.   

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Our client Lucila is 30 years old and a single mother who has two children. She alternates between house work and her job as a promoter of selling “Master Food”. The client’s character and desire are characterized by the jewelry store she opened. She has the will power to move forward and to ensure her two children will be professionals. Its been many years since she had this business and it has gone well thanks to the determination that she puts into her job. Our client is a hard working and enterprising mother that moves her family forward despite not counting on her ex-husband, the father of their two children. She requires a loan to buy more merchandise like bracelets, earrings, rings and necklaces.

She belongs to the communal bank “Huayna CCAPAC” of Asociación Arariwa in the Cusco Province, Department of Cusco. She is grateful for the opportunity provided by this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by karl baumgarten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The client requires a loan to buy more merchandise like rings, bracelets, necklaces and earings

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr: Pour subvenir à ses propres besoins, cette jeune femme s’est lancée en 1998 dans le commerce de poissons fumés, elle va s’approvisionner  très tôt au port de pêche de Lomé et pour toucher un plus grand nombre de clients elle fait son commerce de façon ambulante, voulant se réapprovisionner elle s’adresse à WAGES pour obtenir son premier crédit, ainsi elle pourra acheter 6 cartons de gros poissons et 4 paniers de petits poissons.
texts.en:
To support herself, this young woman got into the business of selling smoked fish in 1998. She gets supplies very early from the fishing port of Lomé and, to reach more customers, she does business door-to-door. Wanting to restock, she is turning to WAGES for her first loan in order to buy 6 boxes of large fish and 4 baskets of small fish.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of baskets of fish

loans.name: Claudina

texts.es: La señora  CLAUDINA R. D. O. tiene 60 años, vive en el distrito del PORVENIR, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. Pertenece al Banco Comunal CARIDAD II. La socia presenta estudios hasta 6to D. primaria, es casada  y tiene 6 hijos D. los cuales 1 depenD. económicamente D. ella. La socia se dedica a la venta D. productos alimenticios como: galletas, gaseosas, cerveza, arroz, azúcar, etc. Este es su primer crédito D. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo utilizará para abastecer su tienda con mas productos para poder aumentar sus ventas y sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Claudina R. D. O. is 60. She lives in the Porvenir district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She belongs to the Caridad II Communal Bank. She went to school until the sixth graD.. She is married and has six children. One child is economically dependent upon her. She sells food products like crackers, soft drinks, beer, rice, and sugar, etc. This is her first loan for 300 PEN. She will use it to stock her store with more products. She will do this to be able to increase her sales and her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy crackers, soft drinks, beer, rice, and sugar, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase and sale of spare parts

loans.name: Ami Massan

texts.fr: Cette jeune femme s’est lancée pour sa toute première fois dans le commerce de pagnes, plus tard elle y a associé le commerce de mèches et de produits de beauté, ce qui a contribué a accroître son chiffre d’affaire. la période des fêtes de fin d’année a entrainé une hausse de la demande, elle voudrait en profiter pour maximiser son profit raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter  12 pièces de pagnes de qualité HI-Target, 10  cartons de mèches et divers produits de beauté. Etant célibataire, c’est cette activité qui lui permet de bien subvenir à ses propres besoins.
texts.en:
This young woman initially got started in the commerce of pagnes (colorful West African cloth). Later on, she included commerce in hair extensions and beauty products. This has helped to increase her sales. The year-end holiday period has lead to a jump in demand. She would like to take advantage of it to maximize her profits. For these reasons, she's requesting a WAGES loan to buy 12 bolts of quality HI-Target pagnes, 10 boxes of hair extensions, and a variety of beauty products. Her business really enables her to support herself, being unmarried.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth, hair extensions, and beauty products

loans.name: Mujeres Victoriosas Group

texts.es:
Este comité integrada por 18 mujeres emprendedoras se encuentra en  décimo ciclo. Cada una de la integrantes cuenta con un Perfil diferente ya que cada una se dedica a  una actividad independiente  y se detalla como sigue: 
Maria E. V..Venta de mercaderias
Elida V..Venta de comestible
Maria F. M.Venta de merceria
Maria i. M.Venta  de carbòn
Maria Perez.Venta de Ropas
Isabel L..Venta de frutas 
Fermina A..Venta de empanadas
Teresa T..Venta de ropas
Ancia Teresa L..Venta de plateria
Johana G..Venta de ropas
Maria Natalia T..Venta de Tele Bingo
Angela Lucia O..Modista
Mariza M..Venta de lenceria
Maria Liz  M..Venta de cosmeticos 
Yolanda A..Venta de comidas
Ester A..Venta de frutas
Luciana G..Venta de ropas
Sandra M..Peluquera
 Se puede mencionar el caso especifico de la señora la Sra. Angela Lucia O. quien tiene 38 años de edad , con un 1 hijo que se queda con la  vecina  ya que su mama  Doña Angela trabaja fuera de su casa, además de su trabajo ambulante en su casa los fines de semana ella confecciona ropas para criatura y  sabanas sale a vender por los asentamientos. Su  sueño es tener una  casa propia, actualmente tiene una casita  precaria hecha de pedasos de tablas, a través de la ayuda de la  Fundación desea refaccionar su pequeña casita.
texts.en:
This group is comprised of 18 enterprising women who are in their 10th loan cycle. Each one of these members has a different profile because each one has a unique independent business that is explained as follows: Maria E. V.: merchandise sales Elida V.: foodstuff sales Maria F. Meaurio: notions sales Maria i. Mareno: coal sales Maria Perez: clothing sales Isabel L.: fruit sales Fermina A.: the sale of empanadas Teresa T.: clothing sales Ancia Teresa L.: silverware sales Johana G.: clothing sales Maria Natalia T.: Tele Bingo sales Angela Lucia O.: dressmaker/designer Mariza M.: lingerie sales Maria Liz M.: cosmetics sales Yolanda A.: food sales Ester A..Venta: fruit sales Luciana G.: clothing sales Sandra M.: beauty parlor It is worth mentioning the specific case of Señora Angela Lucia O.. Angela is 38 years old and has one child who she leaves with a neighbor since her mother, Doña Angela, works outside of the house. In addition to her business selling in the street, during the weekends she makes clothing for infants and bed sheets and sells them in the housing settlements. Her dream is to have her own house; currently she has a meager cottage that is built with planks of wood. With the help of the Foundation she would like to renovate her small cottage.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy Bingo cards for sale, fabrics for dressmaking, work tools and merchandise such as fruit, flour, pasta, eggs, rice, sugar, clothing and household utensils

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Mrs. Hawa J. is 46 years old and is married with six children: two girls and four boys. She lives in Freetown, the capital city of Sierra Leone.

With her previous loan, Hawa expanded her business by purchasing more bags of cement, crates of drinks and bags of sachet water (water sold in plastic bags).

Hawa hopes to secure this loan so she can improve her business, which will enable her to care for her family. With this loan she will purchase more bags of cement, crates of drinks and sachets of water. The profit will be used to further enhance her business.

loans.use: To boost business by purchasing more bags of cement, crates of drinks and sachets of water

loans.name: Jose Alfonso

texts.es:
José P. de 27 años de edad, vive en el sector de la Perimetral de Guayaquil,  cuenta en su vivienda con agua, alcantarillado, luz y caminos pavimentados su casa es de ladrillos pero quiere seguir construyéndola, José se dedico a la venta de víveres hace ya muchos años atrás ya que vio que todos sus familiares han tenido negocios similares y han sido prosperados e independientes y el decidió que fuera igual su futuro.
